definition: An-Shi Rebellion (755-763) of 安祿山|安禄山[An1 Lu4 shan1] and 史思明[Shi3 Si1 ming2], a catastrophic setback for Tang dynasty
content/calm/still/quiet/safe/secure/in good health/to find a place for/to install/to fix/to fit/to bring (a charge against sb)/to pacify/to harbor (good intentions)/security/safety/peace/ampere
surname An
history/annals/title of an official historian in ancient China
surname Shi
(possessive particle, literary equivalent of 的[de5])/him/her/it
in confusion or disorder/in a confused state of mind/disorder/upheaval/riot/illicit sexual relations/to throw into disorder/to mix up/indiscriminate/random/arbitrary

sentences.english: It typically reflects the tragic fate of literal man of Tang flouring age after Anshi Rebellion.
sentences.chinese: 它典型地反映了盛唐文人在安史之亂後的悲劇命運。

sentences.english: Anshi's Rebellion is the indication of the new epoch to the poetry.
sentences.chinese: 安史之亂對於詩歌來說，標誌着一個新時代的開始。

sentences.english: Adds Anlushan Rebellion's reason, causes Tang Dynasty's national strength to decline day after day.
sentences.chinese: 加之安史之亂的原因，使唐朝的國力日漸衰退。

sentences.english: The power of the eunuch had taken place great changes since An-shi Rebellion in Tang Dynasty.
sentences.chinese: 唐代宦官的權勢經安史之亂髮生了重大的變化。

sentences.english: In the Tang Dynasty , An Lushan and Shi Siming led an armed rebellion . Many ministers either surrendered or fled .
sentences.chinese: 唐朝安史之亂期間，許多大臣都投降或者逃跑了。

sentences.english: The phenomenon of renting land between personal is more and more after An Shi Rebellion.
sentences.chinese: 安史之亂後，私人出租和租借土地的現象越來越多。

sentences.english: The An-Shi Rebellion, which broke out in 755 and lasted for 8 years, bought great disasters to the Tang Dynasty.
sentences.chinese: “安史之亂”持續了八年，造成巨大的社會災難。

definition: An Lushan (703-757), Tang general, leader of the An-Shi Rebellion 安史之亂|安史之乱[An1 Shi3 zhi1 Luan4]
Tang and Song dynasty provincial governor, in Tang times having military and civil authority, but only civil authority in Song
ancient official title

History of the Early Tang Dynasty, sixteenth of the 24 dynastic histories 二十四史[Er4 shi2 si4 Shi3], compiled under Liu Xu 劉昫|刘昫[Liu2 Xu4] in 945 during Later Jin 後晉|后晋[Hou4 Jin4] of the Five Dynasties, 200 scrolls
Wei State (407-225 BC), one of the Seven Hero States of the Warring States 戰國七雄|战国七雄/Wei State or Cao Wei 曹魏 (220-265), the most powerful of the Three Kingdoms
to go on a punitive expedition
Baoying county in Yangzhou 揚州|扬州[Yang2 zhou1], Jiangsu
(old) to transport by water/to ship grain as tax
peasant revolt
Zanhuang county in Shijiazhuang 石家莊|石家庄[Shi2 jia1 zhuang1], Hebei
Zhang Juzheng (1525-1582), Grand Secretary during the Ming dynasty, credited with bringing the dynasty to its apogee
to banish from the court/to relegate
to sacrifice one's life by loyalty (to one's prince, one's husband etc)
Emperor Xuan (91-48 BC) of the Former Han Dynasty, reigned 74-48 BC
commander-in-chief, the equivalent of king in Chinese chess
